title: 106_hr2577
content: The Act titled "Jackson Multi-Agency Campus Act of 1999" is established for the purpose of creating a multi-agency campus. The Act titled "Jackson Multi-Agency Campus Act of 1999" aims to consolidate various agencies and entities in Jackson, Wyoming onto one site to improve communication and reduce costs. The Act aims to consolidate agencies in Jackson, Wyoming onto one site to improve communication, reduce costs, and better serve the public. It authorizes agencies to develop and maintain the Project, provide resources, and convey federally owned land for construction of facilities. The Act aims to consolidate agencies in Jackson, Wyoming onto one site to improve communication, reduce costs, and better serve the public. It authorizes the conveyance of federally owned land for the construction of facilities for the Bridger-Teton National Forest by the town of Jackson, Wyoming, and the relinquishment of certain reversionary interests of the United States to facilitate the transactions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the Game and Fish Commission of Wyoming, construction costs meeting Federal standards, a specific Federal parcel on Bridger-Teton National Forest, a map and master plan related to a multi-agency campus project site. The "master plan" refers to a document for a proposed multi-agency campus project in Wyoming. The "Project" involves constructing administrative and visitor facilities. The "Secretary" is the Secretary of Agriculture. The "State parcel" is a 3-acre land for the project. The "State parcel" is a 3-acre land in Wyoming, specifically in the town of Jackson. SEC. 4. MULTI-AGENCY CAMPUS PROJECT, JACKSON, WYOMING. The town may offer to construct an administrative facility for the Bridger-Teton National Forest in exchange for Federal land. The Commission may offer to convey a portion of the State parcel for the same purpose. If the offers are made within 5 years of the Act's enactment, the Secretary shall convey the land accordingly. The Secretary will convey Federal land to the Commission in exchange for a portion of the State parcel, as specified in the Act. The Secretary will convey portions of the Federal parcel to the town and the Commission as part of the land exchange. The United States will also relinquish reversionary interests in the State parcel as additional consideration. The exchanged interests must be of equal value. The fair market and improvement values of the land to be exchanged under this Act shall be determined by appraisals acceptable to the Secretary, in accordance with federal standards. Each appraisal report must adhere to Federal standards and not consider any reversionary interests held by the United States. The Secretary will adjust the acreage of Federal land conveyed to a town based on the value compared to construction costs. If the land value is higher, the acreage will be reduced, and if it is lower, additional land may be conveyed. Federal land conveyed to the Commission must be of equal value to State parcel. The value of Federal land conveyed to the Commission must be equal to the State parcel's value. Boundaries can be adjusted to equalize values. Cash payment may be made to equalize values if adjusting parcel sizes or conveying additional land compromises the Project's design. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS. Construction of facilities on Federal land within the Project boundaries shall be supervised and managed by the town to approved standards. The town, including contractors, shall have access to the land for construction purposes. Land acquired by the United States under this Act will be governed by national forest site laws. No construction is allowed in wetland areas after the land conveyance date. Deeds and conveyance documents will include necessary reservations. Deeds and conveyance documents executed by the Secretary under this Act will include reservations to prevent wetland development on Federal parcels.
